↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Carbonyl: a New Graphical Web Browser in Your Linux Terminal Long-time Slashdot reader destinyland writes: Someone made a Chromium fork... for your terminal. The terminal-based browser Carbonyl "adheres to, and is compatible with modern standards," writes MUO, "meaning that pages behave as they should, and you can even watch streaming video, within the Linux terminal!"

@slashdot@feeds.twtxt.net This is bloody crazy ü§£ Cool but useless üòÖ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic OK, I fixed this. I hadn't set any of the SMTP values for my pod. I tested a few features that would send emails, and they did.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Yeah kind of makes sense.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @kaniyama_t Hello! üëã I see you've spun up a new Yarn pod? ü§î I think you're the operator? ü§î

You are right, you can‚Äôt really block access to the twtxt.txt (feed) itself, that‚Äôs kind of how it works. But you can basically just create an ‚Äúisolated‚Äù pod if that makes sense? ‚Äì You _could also put a reverse proxy in front of your pod with a password. Highly recommend Authelia for this üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @kaniyama_t Hello! üëã I see you've spun up a new Yarn pod? ü§î I think you're the operator? ü§î

@kaniyama_t@yarn.takuma-csirt.com So, if you want to have a more ‚Äúprivate‚Äù pod, I think the best way to do this right now is:

  • Block all feeds (Settings -> Poderator Settings -> Blocked Feeds) and used .* as the only pattern / regular expression.
  • Show ‚ÄúLocal Only‚Äù posts for Discover (Settings -> Poderator Settings)

See example screenshot here:

Turns out you can‚Äôt just shove the extra data- attributes on the a tag like you‚Äôd expect, no no, you have to shove ‚Äòem on some unrelated i element that‚Äôs used for the icon. da fuq?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
